articles.headline: Retirees Filling the Front Line in Market Fears
articles.snippet: Older Americans with investments are among the hardest hit, and have the least opportunity to recover.
articles.abstract: Older Americans with investments are among the hardest hit, and have the least opportunity to recover.
articles.lead_paragraph: Older Americans with investments are among the hardest hit by the turmoil in the financial markets and have the least opportunity to recover.
articles.byline: By John Leland and Louis Uchitelle

articles.headline: Friction Infiltrates Sunni Patrols on Safer Iraqi Streets
articles.snippet: The Sunni-dominated citizen patrols paid by the Americans to fight the insurgency have become increasingly unpredictable.
articles.abstract: The Sunni-dominated citizen patrols paid by the Americans to fight the insurgency have become increasingly unpredictable.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD  In Adhamiya, a neighborhood that only a year ago was among the most dangerous in Baghdad, the violence last week seemed almost negligible. A shootout near a checkpoint left two people dead on Sunday. Another man was killed on Monday by a small bomb placed under a car.

articles.headline: With Google Phone, HTC Comes Out of the Shadows
articles.snippet: For much of the past decade, the Taiwanese manufacturer operated in relative obscurity as a contract manufacturer for many carriers.
articles.abstract: For much of the past decade, the Taiwanese manufacturer operated in relative obscurity as a contract manufacturer for many carriers.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  When executives from Google and T-Mobile converge on a stage in New York Tuesday to unveil the first mobile phone powered by Google’s software, the event will be a coming-out party of sorts for another, far more obscure, but no less ambitious company  HTC.
articles.byline: By Miguel Helft and Laura M. Holson

articles.headline: Bailout Talks Advance, but Doubts Voiced in Congress
articles.snippet: Discussions with the Bush administration have addressed measures such as increased oversight and aid for homeowners at risk of foreclosure.
articles.abstract: Discussions with the Bush administration have addressed measures such as increased oversight and aid for homeowners at risk of foreclosure.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Bush administration and Congressional leaders moved closer to agreement on a historic $700 billion bailout for financial firms on Monday, including tight oversight of the program and new efforts to help homeowners at risk of foreclosure.

articles.headline: Experts See a Need for Punitive Action in Bailout
articles.snippet: While most economists say the crisis justifies an intervention, there is debate over how to do it.
articles.abstract: While most economists say the crisis justifies an intervention, there is debate over how to do it.
articles.lead_paragraph: As economists puzzle over the proposed details of what may be the biggest financial bailout in American history, the initial skepticism that greeted its unveiling has only deepened.

articles.headline: Suit Claims Fund Gave a Heads Up
articles.snippet: An investor has sued the Reserve Fund, a big mutual fund operator, accusing of it tipping other investors to impending losses.
articles.abstract: An investor has sued the Reserve Fund, a big mutual fund operator, accusing of it tipping other investors to impending losses.
articles.lead_paragraph: By the time the Reserve Fund reported last Tuesday afternoon that its Primary Fund money market funds had “broken the buck”  that is, were no longer worth a dollar a share  investors had already withdrawn billions of dollars from the fund.

articles.headline: Last Two Big Investment Banks Reinvent Their Businesses
articles.snippet: As Morgan Stanley and Goldman Sachs restructure as regulated bank holding companies, Wall Street will be an arena of greater stability and smaller profits.
articles.abstract: As Morgan Stanley and Goldman Sachs restructure as regulated bank holding companies, Wall Street will be an arena of greater stability and smaller profits.
articles.lead_paragraph: Over the years, Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley have established their gilded reputations advising companies how to remake themselves, often in hostile environments.
articles.byline: By Ben White and Louise Story

articles.headline: With Bailout Picture Unclear, Markets Tumble
articles.snippet: The Dow Jones industrials closed down 372 points, or 3.3 percent, at 11,015.69 after spending the day deep in negative territory.
articles.abstract: The Dow Jones industrials closed down 372 points, or 3.3 percent, at 11,015.69 after spending the day deep in negative territory.
articles.lead_paragraph: Fresh concerns about the biggest government bailout in history sent stock markets down sharply on Monday, while a weakening dollar sparked a frantic rush into commodities as investors remained nervous about the health of Wall Street.
articles.byline: By Jad Mouawad and Michael M. Grynbaum

articles.headline: A Bailout Above the Law
articles.snippet: The proposed legislation is the financial equivalent of the Patriot Act.
articles.abstract: The proposed legislation is the financial equivalent of the Patriot Act.

articles.headline: This Season, Tense Times for Retailers
articles.snippet: Not only are retailers grappling with a sputtering economy, but the credit crisis is making it harder for them to finance operations.
articles.abstract: Not only are retailers grappling with a sputtering economy, but the credit crisis is making it harder for them to finance operations.
articles.lead_paragraph: For many of the nation’s retailers, this is shaping up to be the most critical holiday season since the recession of the early 1980s. Chains that fare poorly could end up as ghosts of Christmases past.
